job_title: Community Integration Assistant in Evansville, IN
pros: Rewarding position. I loved working with the clients and enjoyed working with the staff.
cons: Amazing people for the most part. The only negative I can think of is it can be a rumor mill, which happens everywhere it just felt a little extra here. That and sometimes you don't feel heard as a client advocate.

job_title: in Evansville, IN
pros: The job truly prepares you for being a knowledgeable clinician and the pay is mostly fair.  Most of the bosses there are reasonable (most), and the new CEOs for both healthcare and behavioral are both amazing people.  The therapists genuinely care about their patients and seem very focused on honing their craft to better their clients.  The PTO is amazing.  7 hours every 2 weeks with a cap of 182.  After 5 years it's 8 hours every 2 weeks with a max of 208.  They also add a little to your 401k, which is nice.
cons: A few of the other branches I've heard nightmares about. Moran was a good experience.  Spear has a good team from what a friend reports.  some of the stories I've heard about stepping stone have been attrocious.  The insurance is expensive.  If you get the high deductible, it's only good if you happen to get cancer or are in a brutal accident.

review_title: A good part-time, entry-level position, but not ideal for long-term employment.
job_title: Mental Health Technician in Lincoln, NE
pros: If you like independence, this job allows you to work alone with very little supervision for most of your shifts.  There are some long stretches of time during the day that require very little work, and some days are actually pretty fun.  You get to develop a rapport with clients.  It was also very, very easy to get hired.  If you're a normal, sort of reliable person, you'll get the job.
cons: This job paid very, very poorly.  The work was fairly difficult, if you actually wanted to make a difference in people's lives.  There was no pay increase based on education, and salaries were somewhat arbitrarily decided upon.  One employee demanded $12 an hour, but had no degree, while others had a B.S. in psychology and made right around $10 an hour.  Raises amounted to a few cents a year, and were not handed out based on merit.

job_title: Integrated Skills Assistant in Evansville, IN
pros: This job requires a lot of patience and teamwork. I feel that my co workers, management, and Southwestern as whole works together to make this job the best it can be. I also love that we are helping those who most would not to be successful. It is a very rewarding job with great benefits as well!
cons: High turnover rate of employees due to school, BUT they work hard to give us schedules that reflect a good work life balance.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Evansville, IN
pros: Great benefits that started immediately.  Loved my coworkers.  Loved the clients.  The job can be stressful at time but you feel appreciated.  Raises are given on your performance.  I would recommend this company to friends and family.  I left because I graduated from college and wanted to use my degree.
cons: Clients can sometimes be difficult but that is the nature of mental illness sometimes.

job_title: Lcsw in Evansville, IN
pros: Great company who works hard to provide excellent care and take of its employees at the same. It’s a nonprofit organization that really focuses on direct care for low income and low resources clients.
cons: Communication care be tough when your company is in 4 counties.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Evansville, IN
pros: It is very rewarding when clients come back to visit and are sober and doing very well.
cons: They are non for profit so the paychecks did not reflect the amount or work the staff exerted on a daily basis.
